A & B, Both are correct. More precise is B.
The requirement “output must be sorted by the number of weeks, starting with the longest” means the sorting order MUST be DESC on Tenure (High -- Low)
Since in C & D, the order by tenure will adopt ASC by default, it will be from low -High so lowest tenure will be on top of output and highest tenure at bottom.

choices.B: A synonym can be available to all users.
choices.D: Any user can drop a PUBLIC synonym.
choices.C: A SEQUENCE can have a synonym.
choices.E: A synonym created by one user can refer to an object belonging to another user.
choices.A: A synonym cannot be created for a PL/SQL package.

comments.content:
D. EXPIRY_DATE cannot be used in arithmetic expressions.

False. You can use Arithmetic expressions in Dates, just not all of them.
SELECT 
 DATE'2023-05-20' - 1 AS expire_date, 
 DATE'2023-05-20' + 1 AS extra_day
FROM DUAL;

I agree that the primary key could contain duplicated values, but is the one that seems most feasible out of the remaining options.

B is wrong, absence of data means null. An arithmetic operation with a null value always yields null

choices.F: PRODUCT_ID can be assigned the PRIMARY KEY constraint.
choices.D: EXPIRY_DATE cannot be used in arithmetic expressions.
choices.A: EXPIRY_DATE contains the SYSDATE by default if no date is assigned to it.
choices.B: PRODUCT_PRICE can be used in an arithmetic expression even if it has no value stored in it.
choices.E: PRODUCT_PRICE contains the value zero by default if no value is assigned to it.

discussion.content: Correct answer: C and E

Cannot use aliases in WHERE clause:

ORA-00904: "ANNUAL_SALARY": invalid identifier

A - logical typo but still will work
B - Won't work because if _ is missing oracle does not recognize column (invalid identifier)
C - Won't work because you can't use aliases in where clause 
D - Works
E - The same as C
F - Works 
Answers : A, C, E
Tested on Oracle live
C and E because of the alias used in the where clause

AB -> typos
CE -> fails
